title: Wright Prospecting reaps bumper profit on iron ore recovery
text:
The descendants of Pilabara pioneer Peter Wright enjoyed a $172 million dividend in 2018-19, as the company which collects royalties from the iron ore tenements, he pegged with Lang Hancock in the 1960s saw profits leap on higher prices and lower legal fees.

Wright Prospecting, which is jointly owned by Wright's daughter Angela Bennett, and two of the daughters of her late brother Michael Wright, Leonie Baldock and Alexandra Burt, made a $160.6 million net profit after tax in the year to 30 June 2019, up from $127.4 million the prior year.

Revenues increased to $237 million from $193 million the prior year, which Wright Prospecting's board attributed to higher average commodity prices despite decreased shipment volumes during the year.

The 2018-19 financial report is the first that Wright Prospecting has ever lodged with the corporate regulator in an orderly manner, after it submitted 20 years' worth of reports at once in December last year.

The reports laid bare the huge passive income that Angela Bennett and her nieces continue to receive from Wright's work six decades ago.

Ms Bennett's AMB Holdings, and Ms Baldock and Ms Burt's VOC Group, collectively received a $173 million dividend from Wright Prospecting in 2017-18, following $106 million and $424 million payments the two prior years.
description: The tenements pegged by Peter Wright and Lang Hancock in the 1960s continue to pay off handsomely, although massive legal bills are an unwelcome part of the legacy.
